title: Does Putin really want to re-unite the Soviet Union? - Quora

response.answer_text: I have not heard any Putin's speech, where he called for the restoration of the USSR. Here we can imagine the following analogy. Imagine a huge dormitory in which they live different families in their rooms. They seem to be independent from each other, but are common goods, food, warmth and comfort. There will always be family, which almost all have their own, but the rest of the family she suffers only from their additional contribution to the common pot. So the Soviet Union existed. Had the Republic which are almost completely subsidized from other republics, but all believed that they give more than I receive. They built factories, but worked there cleaned the Russian people. Local people are often beyond trade and administrative functions are not humiliated. After the collapse of the Soviet Union was a disaster for many countries. They were not able to develop independently without the help of Russia. So the whole Baltic concerted series went to Europe for alms. They certainly helped, and in gratitude they had become enemies of the Russian Federation. Guess three times who is more Russophobia in the international arena Lithuania, Latvia or Estonia? Betrayal - their fate! Do we need are allies who can at any time change their ancestors and the rising generation. Because of momentary preferences completely abandon former friends and try to buy a new one. I think they did not succeed in this field. Time will tell! Russia currently completely freed from dependence on the former Soviet republics and can quite happily exist on its own. Return to the previous anymore. For inclusion in the Union with Russia, many republics still need to Mature and do a lot to establish normal relations with a former friend. I think that in the near future course of unification with Russia will not, but only sovereign States enter into an economic Union with preserving their independence, that we are quite satisfied.

What are the main features of the USSR? In my opinion they are: - communist ideology; - strict state dictatorship in all spheres; - strict centralisation of power (no separation in independent legislative, executive and judicial powers); - complete lack of influence of citizens on power; - total irresponsibility of state officials to citizens; - significant militarization of society; - preferance to international politics to the detriment of internal affairs. Let's stop here. So do you think Putin wants to restore all these? I do not think so. I guess his goal is to restore all these but the communist ideology. Communist ideology would not justify the existence of his friends oligarchs, so he does not need this ideology. All the rest is quite OK for him. So I do not think that he wants to restore the USSR. He just wants to build a state system where he will be able to do whatever he likes without giving anyone an account of own actions. Like an absolutist monarchy.

It would have been utterly impractical and Putin is not stupid (even though had he had even a minuscule chance to restore the Soviet empire, he would’ve grabbed it literally at all costs: Putin considers its loss the single most abominable social catastrophe of the last century). The time of the former empires like the British or Belgian one, like the one of the USSR, of France or Holland, is gone irreversibly due to reversed global mentality based on Internet. What Putin wants and so far has been successful in pursuing is to turn Russia into an equal global player with the other two most dominant political powers of our time: the U.S. and emerging China. More and more it is becoming obvious that at our time the global political power is parallel to the size of a country; the time of the tiny Britain ruling the world is over. Russia’s sheer size makes it a very valid ‘candidate’ (as is true for the U.S. and China). True, Russia as of today is still far behind the other two in economic power, the second necessary component, but at least Putin successfully tries to establish the Russian political dominance using so to say an American template: through global military bases and diplomatic influence, to play “my enemy’s enemy is my friend” card, to meddle and disrupt whatever possible to diminish the U.S. and China’s domination. Of course, but of course, Putin’s final golden goal is to achieve the ultimately superior status vs U.S. and/or China (not only level the field); so far this is a blue dream far away as Russian economy today still is incomparably weaker, but Putin has stepped on this road already, even if at the very beginning; he is on his way.

Putin said: “Whoever does not miss the Soviet Union has no heart. Whoever wants it back has no brain.” By his standards I do not have a heart. I do not think he wants to recreate the Soviet Union. He is concentrating on Russia. He clearly works in any way possible to make Russia into a global superpower that it once was. In the long run, I do not think this is possible, because of relatively small economy, and one-sided nature of it, in Russia. But in military terms, Putin has made Russia into a superpower: As much as I abhor that, I have to admit it.

response.answer_text: Putin does not want to have the USSR back. It is a very incorrect presumption. He wants to reinforce ties between former Soviet republics, even if that means providing them more aid to help them out of their troubles, but to create a tighter political alliance and market system, based on cultural closeness and common need for a stronger international stand.

A2A Putin doesn't cherish megalomaniac projects. His ends are stated clearly in a simple comprehensible to all language. Most of all, the state targets which he establishes are invariably feasible, supported by the available means and include the strategic aim of keeping constant grow of the individual well-being of the citizen. Putin regards the autonomy of a nation as the value of the highest rate. He stands against politics of politico-economic-military blocks. It takes a petrified brain not to realize that paradoxically as it maybe sounds the US nowadays in large part of its international policy-making more and more resembles the anachronistic policy of the Soviet post-Stalin talent-less idiots, like Khrushchev Gorbachev and Yeltsin. Thanks for asking Niek De Lepper.

No, the restoration of the Soviet Union i is impossible, and Putin understands this. However, he views the former Soviet republics as Russia's sphere of influence, key to the security of Russian borders. Therefore, he reacts very sharply to the attempts of the US and the EU to interfere in the affairs of the former Soviet republics, or to include them in the NATO military Alliance.

Putin wants to restore the Russian Empire (not the USSR) in it’s 19th century borders. Permanent heating of conflict in Osetia and Abhazia, war on the territory of Georgia in 2008, Crimea and occupation of Donbas in 2014. Trying to incorporate Belarus (even Lukashenko has objected to those efforts). Nuclear missiles in Kalningrad oblast.

Putin is trying to restore Russia's sphere of influence, which inevitably jogs recent memories of Soviet sphere of influence in people who haven't really understood the difference last 30 years have made for Russia. Putin himself, however, is notorious for constantly betraying the expectations of anyone who expects him to go full Stalin.

Russia historically hardly ever did “very well”, so that isn’t a major consideration with Putin. Instead, Russia’s specialty has always been expansion. When Ivan the Terrible was first annointed, Russia was only marginally larger than some other european states. Ivan approximately doubled that, and his heirs and successors continued until the Russian Empire was truly monstrous in size. Stalin continued that tradition, into the Baltics, Fenno-Scandinavia, and Central Europe. Brezhnev tried in Afghanistan, no matter that the Soviet Union had lapsed into stagnation. Why should Putin be any different?

I personally believe that cooperation is the best for everyone. Also, we can see that there are many trade groups, area cooperations, and strategic alliance around the world, and countries benefited from them. Meanwhile, the reason of past unsuccessful experience of Soviet Union is not the Union itself, but the complex political issue. For example, you and me in a team, work on a project for profits, but failed because of my bad personality. Does it mean that you should not work in team? And if I corrected my bad personality, shouldn’t we give another try?
No, he said that those who want to restore the USSR is insane. But re-union of former USSR republics as a new state can be a great thing.
